title: Introduction to Python & Data
text:
Welcome!
Python is a powerful programming language that is popular can be used to write scripts for to work effectively and reproducibly with data. In this workshop, we aim to give you the tools to start exploring Python and all it has to offer by yourself.
Our workshop material is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. You can view the license here.

title: 6  Introduction to python
text:
7.2 Variables, values and their types

text = "Data Carpentry"
number = 42
pi_value = 3.141592653589793238462643383279502884197


text

'Data Carpentry'



type(text)

str



number

42



type(number)

int



pi_value

3.141592653589793



type(pi_value)

float

title: 6  Introduction to python
text:
7.3 Output versus printing
In this example we first print the number and then call the variable again:

print(number)
number

42


42


Now we do it the other way around:

number
print(number)

42


The interpreter does not output the value of the variable unless it is the very last line in an input field. In general print is the only way to print output to the screen when you are not working in an interactive environment as Jupyter, but when you are working with scripts. Rule of thumb: use output for quick checking while developing your Jupyter notebook, use print for all output that needs to be there while running a Jupyter notebook.

summing = 2 + 2
multiply = 6 * 7
power = 2 ** 16
modulo = 13 % 5

print("Sum: ", summing)
print("Multiply: ", multiply)
print("Power: ", power)
print("Modulo: ", modulo)

Sum:  4
Multiply:  42
Power:  65536
Modulo:  3

title: 6  Introduction to python
text:
7.4 Logical values, operators and variables
There are two logical values, true and false. Inpython they are decoded as the values True and False. Note: here these two are really distinct values and no strings!

True

True



False

False


With the logical operators >, <, ==, and, or and not we can now compare variables and create logical statements.

compare = 3 > 4
print("3 > 4 : ", compare)

3 > 4 :  False



not_compare = not compare
print("not(3 > 4): ", not_compare)

not(3 > 4):  True



compare or not_compare

True



compare and not_compare

False



True or False

True



True and False

False



True == compare

False

title: 6  Introduction to python
text:
7.5 The if-statement
We saw how to create logical statements. In the if-clause we use these as conditional statements to carry some tasks.

title: 6  Introduction to python
text:
7.6 Lists and Tuples

numbers = [1, 2, 3]
numbers[0]

1



type(numbers)

list



len(numbers)

3



numbers[3]

IndexError: list index out of range



numbers[-1]

3



numbers[2] == numbers[-1]

True



words = ["cat", "dog", "horse"]
words[1]

'dog'



type(words)

list



if type(words) == type(numbers):
    print("these variables have the same type!")

these variables have the same type!



newlist = ["cat", 1, "horse"]


type(newlist[0])

str



type(newlist[1])

int



numbers.append(4)
print(numbers)

[1, 2, 3, 4]



numbers[2] = 333
print(numbers)

[1, 2, 333, 4]



# Tuples use parentheses
a_tuple = (1, 2, 3)
another_tuple = ('blue', 'green', 'red')

# Note: lists use square brackets
a_list = [1, 2, 3]


a_list[1] = 5
print(a_list)

[1, 5, 3]



a_tuple[2] = 5
print(a_tuple)

TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment



type(a_tuple)

tuple

title: 6  Introduction to python
6  Introduction to python
text:
7.8 For loops

numbers = [5, 6, 7]


for item in numbers:
    print(item)

5
6
7



words = ["cat", "dog", "horse"]
for index, item in enumerate(words):
    print(index)
    print(item)

0
cat
1
dog
2
horse



for key, value in my_dict.items():
    print(key, '->', value)

one -> first
two -> second
third -> three

title: 6  Introduction to python
text:
7.9 Exercises

7.9.1 Exercise 0
Try to run this code. Why is there no output?

x = 6
apple = "apple"



7.9.2 Exercise 1

Calculate: One plus five divided by nine.
Assign the result of the calculation to a variable.
Test if the result is larger than one.
Round off the result to one decimal. Use the function round.


s = (1+5)/9
round(s, 1)

0.7




7.9.3 Exercise 2
Predict the results:

5 == 5
not 3 > 2
True == 'True'
False < True

True




7.9.4 Exercise 3
Meet Ann, Bob, Chloe, and Dan. 1. Create a list with their names. Save the list as “name”.

How old are Ann, Bob, Chloe, and Dan? You decide! Design a numeric list with their respective ages. Save it as “age”.
What is their average age? (Use the function sum to sum up their cumulative ages, you can use len(age) to get the number of elements in a list)


name = ["Ann", "Bob", "Chloe", "Dan"]
age = [3, 30, 41, 2]
sum(age)/len(age)

19.0




7.9.5 Exercise 4

Return only the first number in the list age.
Return the 2nd and 4th name in your list name.
Return only ages under 30 from your list age.
Return the name “Chloe” from the list name.


age[0]
[age[1], age[3]]
new_age=[]
for a in age:if a < 30:new_age.append(a)[n for n in name if n == "Chloe"] #or
name[name.index("Chloe")]

SyntaxError: invalid syntax (4124803616.py, line 4)




7.9.6 Exercise 5
Make an if statement that tests if a number is even, and saves the classification in a variable called number_class.

number = 5
if number%2 == 0:
    number_class = "even"
else:
    number_class = "odd"
print(number, "is", number_class)

5 is odd




7.9.7 Exercise 6
Turn the if statement from the last exercise into a function. Let the user provide the value for number, and return the number_class.

def even_or_odd(number):
    if number%2 == 0:
        number_class = "even"
    else:
        number_class = "odd"
    return number_class


number = 5
print(number, "is", even_or_odd(number))

5 is odd




7.9.8 Exercise 7
Use the function above to determine whether the numbers between 1 and 10 are even or odd.

for i in range(1, 11):
    res = even_or_odd(i)
    print(i, 'is', res)

1 is odd
2 is even
3 is odd
4 is even
5 is odd
6 is even
7 is odd
8 is even
9 is odd
10 is even
